local_world_news.summary: But the benefits of the deduction, estimated to cost $31 billion over four years, may be limited to a narrow slice of consumers, economists say.

local_world_news.title: Inside the Surprise Idaho Murders Plea Deal That Left Some Families Fuming
local_world_news.summary: After two and a half years of legal wrangling, prosecutors and lawyers for the defendant, Bryan Kohberger, reached a deal just weeks before his trial was set to begin.

local_world_news.title: Planned Parenthood at Risk of Losing Millions in Federal Funding
local_world_news.summary: The nation’s largest abortion provider must stop offering it in some states or risk losing millions in Medicaid funding to provide basic health care for low-income Americans.

local_world_news.title: Former Criminology Student Is Set to Plead Guilty in Idaho Murders
local_world_news.summary: Bryan Kohberger, now 30, was charged in the 2022 murders that shook the University of Idaho. In exchange, he would avoid a possible death penalty.

local_world_news.title: What the Supreme Court’s Birthright Ruling Means for Trump’s Power
local_world_news.summary: A recent Supreme Court ruling could allow President Trump’s order ending birthright citizenship to go into effect in some states. Abbie VanSickle, a reporter covering the United States Supreme Court for The New York Times, explains how the decision also upends the power of federal judges to freeze policies for the entire country.

local_world_news.title: Trump’s Finances Were Shaky. Then He Began to Capitalize on His Comeback.
local_world_news.summary: Contrary to the president’s assertions, records filed in a fraud case against him suggest that his riches were not the product of a steady and strong empire.

local_world_news.title: Lawmakers Scramble to Reach Washington for Vote on Trump Bill
local_world_news.summary: Hundreds of flights to Washington were canceled because of severe weather, forcing some members of the House to set off on hourslong drives to the Capitol.

local_world_news.title: Lack of New U.S. Sanctions Allows Restricted Goods and Funds Into Russia
local_world_news.summary: President Trump has issued no new restrictions on Russia this year, in effect allowing Moscow to acquire the money and materials it needs in its conflict with Ukraine.

local_world_news.title: Trump Pauses Some Weapons Transfers to Ukraine
local_world_news.summary: The White House cited Pentagon concerns that some American arms stockpiles were dwindling too low. Among the affected weapons were air defense systems, bombs, missiles and artillery rounds.

local_world_news.summary: After scaling back a landmark environmental law, Gov. Gavin Newsom and other state leaders are hoping for a construction boom.

local_world_news.title: U.S. Judge Blocks Deportation of Haitian Migrants
local_world_news.summary: Judge Brian Cogan’s order prevented the Trump administration from ending special immigration protections for hundreds of thousands of Haitian migrants.

local_world_news.title: Trump Says Israel Agrees to Conditions for Gaza Cease-Fire Proposal
local_world_news.summary: In a social media post, the president said the United States and Israel were finalizing a proposal to Hamas. The announcement comes ahead of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s visit to Washington next week.

local_world_news.summary: By ending tax credits for wind and solar power, Senate Republicans may have jeopardized billions in investments in their own districts.

cultural_interest.title: To make out of apparently haphazard circumstances a plotted circle
cultural_interest.summary: The biography of today recoils from stuffing its subject into a straitjacket of interpretation, with all contradictions smoothly reconciled into a unified self. Instead we find an emphasis on the fragility and provisionality of identity, on performance, on motive being mysterious and many-tentacled. from Can You Ever Really Know a Person? Biographers Keep Trying . [NYT Magazine; ungated ]

cultural_interest.title: Green Lanterns of the US Federal Government
cultural_interest.summary: Five hundred eighty six current and former employees of the EPA have posted a signed declaration on the Stand up for Science website shining a light on the pattern of lies and potential violations of the Hatch Act of EPA Director Lee Zeldin .

cultural_interest.title: Thy gown was of the grossie green, thy sleeues of Satten hanging by:
cultural_interest.summary:
The Greensleeves Project "is an interdisciplinary collaboration between a team of established historians and practitioners to look at one of the most famous English historical songs, the Elizabethan ballad of Greensleeves... The earliest surviving text of Greensleeves dates from 1584. It's a long song, with 18 verses, written in a somewhat stalker-like fashion, by a man who showers his would-be beloved with gifts, including a lot of clothes. Put together, these gifts provide us with a rich resource of information on clothing, fabrics, embroidery, and other aspects of material culture." While the website's text will be of interest to some, it's the videos where this project comes to life, especially the video that explains how and why the recreation team made the choices they did when creating the dress, its underpinnings and the sweetmeats (check out the fabulous sugar work at 30:36) gifted to the lady. 

There's also a music video of the song and one by (MeFi favourite) Bernadette Banner describing all of the pieces of attire and explaining their function.

cultural_interest.title: Electric cars for USD20k?  That's the plan
cultural_interest.summary:
Slate Auto is an American startup company that is developing electric vehicles, scheduled for release to the market in late 2026.  Nothing startling there.  What is unusual about their offering is, in large part, the price point - with government rebates the base vehicle starts at USD20k (those rebates have to be at risk, of course because *waves around*).  The base vehicle, dubbed the 'Blank Slate' is an all-electric rear-wheel-drive two-door utility with two seats and a 120 mile (193 km) range.

Youtube channel Rich Rebuilds take a close look at the vehicle here (42:57 YouTube video). The car can be optioned up with additional bolt-on panels to make it a 'fastback' or SUV with five seats, with these additions being made at a dealer level. One example of how they've kept the price point down is the lack of massive touch screens controlling bespoke audio, navigation and other functions.  Instead, a basic touch screen controls your own device via an app.  A big part of the approach, though, is 'reductive manufacturing', where the number of components are reduced to the minimum.  For example, the door armrests are interchangeable not only on all the doors, but the same part is used for the lid of the centre console.

You can have the car in any colour as long as it's grey, but it has been designed to be easily and cheaply wrapped, including the wheels.  Right to Repair has been a strong focus in the design, with composite body panels that can be removed and replaced with just a few screws or bolts as well as the intention to provide specifications and instructions to allow people to service and repair the car themselves.  Aftermarket additions are catered for by fixed 'access points' where accessories can be designed and made using manuals and CAD files to be released by the manufacturer.

Slate Auto has been described as the 'anti-Tesla' and it's perhaps not a mistake that the name is an anagram of Tesla.  With an undisclosed level of funding coming from Jeff Bezos (among others), there's no doubt opinions will be mixed not just because the concept of a cheap, adaptable design has been tried before without much success, but the public perception of Bezos brings a variety of reactions.

cultural_interest.title: Milky Way may crash into another galaxy in 2 billion years
cultural_interest.summary: Milky Way may crash into another galaxy in 2 billion years. It's not Andromeda. A new study challenges predictions our home galaxy the Milky Way will crash into the Andromeda galaxy in 5 billion years .

cultural_interest.title: Seymour Britchky
cultural_interest.summary: "You will note, upon inspection of the menus, that the lobsters served here are identified either as medium or large. When you receive your 'medium' lobster, you will understand at once why nothing could be found to fit the bill of 'small'. This lobster must have been caught with a mosquito net, for he could have slipped the bars of any trap. But when you put on your reading glasses and commence to eat, your dismay is instantly magnified, for what you are not getting enough of is a perfectly broiled lobster, the meat so rich it seems buttery, its flavor vivid enough to make you heady ." For two all-too-brief decades, self-appointed restaurant critic Seymour Britchky made it his mission to capture it all in shockingly astute, hilarious, quotable prose before disappearing in his own right to become one of the city's best-fed (and, essentially, forgotten) ghosts. ... Britchky's people are in it for his acid tongue and gimlet eye—the way he etched a menu, a moment, a space, a feeling, an era in dining when not every plate was Instagram-ready, every interaction Yelp-able to the world. For him, every meal was personal, every review a master class in the art of food writing . ( previously )

cultural_interest.title: Beyond a threshold of similarity, our brain stops making distinctions
cultural_interest.summary: The article introduces the concept of "semantic pareidolia" - our tendency to attribute consciousness, intelligence, and emotions to AI systems that lack these qualities. It examines how this psychological phenomenon leads us to perceive meaning and intentionality in statistical pattern-matching systems, similar to seeing faces in clouds. from AI and Semantic Pareidolia: When We See Consciousness Where There Is None by Luciano Floridi [SSRN]

all_articles.title: Thy gown was of the grossie green, thy sleeues of Satten hanging by:
all_articles.summary:
The Greensleeves Project "is an interdisciplinary collaboration between a team of established historians and practitioners to look at one of the most famous English historical songs, the Elizabethan ballad of Greensleeves... The earliest surviving text of Greensleeves dates from 1584. It's a long song, with 18 verses, written in a somewhat stalker-like fashion, by a man who showers his would-be beloved with gifts, including a lot of clothes. Put together, these gifts provide us with a rich resource of information on clothing, fabrics, embroidery, and other aspects of material culture." While the website's text will be of interest to some, it's the videos where this project comes to life, especially the video that explains how and why the recreation team made the choices they did when creating the dress, its underpinnings and the sweetmeats (check out the fabulous sugar work at 30:36) gifted to the lady. 

There's also a music video of the song and one by (MeFi favourite) Bernadette Banner describing all of the pieces of attire and explaining their function.

all_articles.title: Electric cars for USD20k?  That's the plan
all_articles.summary:
Slate Auto is an American startup company that is developing electric vehicles, scheduled for release to the market in late 2026.  Nothing startling there.  What is unusual about their offering is, in large part, the price point - with government rebates the base vehicle starts at USD20k (those rebates have to be at risk, of course because *waves around*).  The base vehicle, dubbed the 'Blank Slate' is an all-electric rear-wheel-drive two-door utility with two seats and a 120 mile (193 km) range.

Youtube channel Rich Rebuilds take a close look at the vehicle here (42:57 YouTube video). The car can be optioned up with additional bolt-on panels to make it a 'fastback' or SUV with five seats, with these additions being made at a dealer level. One example of how they've kept the price point down is the lack of massive touch screens controlling bespoke audio, navigation and other functions.  Instead, a basic touch screen controls your own device via an app.  A big part of the approach, though, is 'reductive manufacturing', where the number of components are reduced to the minimum.  For example, the door armrests are interchangeable not only on all the doors, but the same part is used for the lid of the centre console.

You can have the car in any colour as long as it's grey, but it has been designed to be easily and cheaply wrapped, including the wheels.  Right to Repair has been a strong focus in the design, with composite body panels that can be removed and replaced with just a few screws or bolts as well as the intention to provide specifications and instructions to allow people to service and repair the car themselves.  Aftermarket additions are catered for by fixed 'access points' where accessories can be designed and made using manuals and CAD files to be released by the manufacturer.

Slate Auto has been described as the 'anti-Tesla' and it's perhaps not a mistake that the name is an anagram of Tesla.  With an undisclosed level of funding coming from Jeff Bezos (among others), there's no doubt opinions will be mixed not just because the concept of a cheap, adaptable design has been tried before without much success, but the public perception of Bezos brings a variety of reactions.

all_articles.title: Milky Way may crash into another galaxy in 2 billion years
all_articles.summary: Milky Way may crash into another galaxy in 2 billion years. It's not Andromeda. A new study challenges predictions our home galaxy the Milky Way will crash into the Andromeda galaxy in 5 billion years .

all_articles.title: Seymour Britchky
all_articles.summary: "You will note, upon inspection of the menus, that the lobsters served here are identified either as medium or large. When you receive your 'medium' lobster, you will understand at once why nothing could be found to fit the bill of 'small'. This lobster must have been caught with a mosquito net, for he could have slipped the bars of any trap. But when you put on your reading glasses and commence to eat, your dismay is instantly magnified, for what you are not getting enough of is a perfectly broiled lobster, the meat so rich it seems buttery, its flavor vivid enough to make you heady ." For two all-too-brief decades, self-appointed restaurant critic Seymour Britchky made it his mission to capture it all in shockingly astute, hilarious, quotable prose before disappearing in his own right to become one of the city's best-fed (and, essentially, forgotten) ghosts. ... Britchky's people are in it for his acid tongue and gimlet eye—the way he etched a menu, a moment, a space, a feeling, an era in dining when not every plate was Instagram-ready, every interaction Yelp-able to the world. For him, every meal was personal, every review a master class in the art of food writing . ( previously )

all_articles.title: Beyond a threshold of similarity, our brain stops making distinctions
all_articles.summary: The article introduces the concept of "semantic pareidolia" - our tendency to attribute consciousness, intelligence, and emotions to AI systems that lack these qualities. It examines how this psychological phenomenon leads us to perceive meaning and intentionality in statistical pattern-matching systems, similar to seeing faces in clouds. from AI and Semantic Pareidolia: When We See Consciousness Where There Is None by Luciano Floridi [SSRN]
